Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Grant: Rhetoric of Quantification in the Context of Chronic Pain

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a doctoral dissertation research project that studies persons with chronic pain. Specifically, the researcher proposes to interview 30 persons with chronic pain who are over 18 and have experienced pain persistently or intermittently for at least three months prior to recruitment. She will conduct 30-60 minute phone interviews, asking open-ended questions about the pain experiences of participants including being in pain, living with pain, and communicating about pain. She will then conduct a rhetorical analysis of interview transcripts for references to quantified information, such as quantified time, quantified medicine, and quantified expenses. The researchers will also identify and analyze other potential trends in how persons with chronic pain describe rhetorical tactics when communicating about their chronic pain. Using rhetorical analysis will allow the researchers to identify persuasive or argumentative strategies or tactics in language use about chronic pain, as described by the people living with and experiencing chronic pain. The researcher will work with regional and national patient advocacy groups and national and international professional associations dedicated to pain treatment. She will develop and disseminate a list of actionable recommendations in a variety of forms, including an accessible one-page overview, invited presentations, and peer-reviewed publication in medical journals. Her overarching goal is to help both persons with chronic pain and the people who communicate with them (including health care providers, caregivers, and loved ones) understand the rhetorical tools and strategies available to persons with chronic pain to articulate their experiences, so that this enhanced understanding might mitigate instances of stigmatization.

This project is an ethnographic study of persons with chronic pain. Between 10% and 30% of the U.S. population lives with chronic pain, and the vast majority of this population reports suffering from undertreated pain, which is further exacerbated by the stigmatization of using drugs and living with physical disability. Given the prevalence, undertreatment, and stigmatization associated with chronic pain, this project seeks to determine whether there is a rhetorical tool or strategy available to persons with chronic pain to help articulate and legitimize their pain experiences for different audiences and stakeholders (health care providers, caregivers, etc.). Anthropologists, philosophers, and bioethicists argue that this stigmatization exists, in part, because pain experience is inherently subjective and cannot be quantitatively measured. Yet, both patients and physicians are accustomed to associating medical practice with objectivity, which is in turn associated with numerical quantification. Although quantifiable information is subject to interpretation, it is because of the overwhelming persuasiveness of quantification in medical and scientific contexts in the United States that the researchers propose to investigate whether a rhetoric of quantification can benefit chronic pain patients seeking legitimization and trust in their articulations of their pain experiences. The findings of this research can advance knowledge about the persuasiveness of quantification as a rhetorical device and further enhance understanding of how objective and subjective knowledge is created, valued, and communicated in U.S. culture, particularly in the context of human health and medicine.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant helped Rachael Graham Lussos conduct interviews with persons with chronic pain as part of her dissertation research on rhetorics of quantification.

To fill a gap in chronic pain research, Dr. Lussos interviewed 49 people with chronic pain. Instead of recruiting participants through their medical networks, she recruited participants through friend-of-friend referrals and social media and conducted interviews by phone. In interviews lasting 30 minutes to 2 hours, she learned about the participants' experiences being in, living with, and communicating with others about their pain. Participants described combinations of nerve pain, muscle pain, joint pain, bone pain, organ pain, and phantom limb pain, with and without formal diagnoses. The NSF STS DDRIG award helped fund transcription of the interviews. Dr. Lussos then conducted a rhetorical analysis of the transcripts.

For her dissertation on the rhetorics of quantification, Dr. Lussos sought to determine whether persons with chronic pain ever quantify their pain. Given the literature on the limitations of the 0-10 numerical pain rating scale (NPRS) and the inherent subjectivity of the nature of pain, Dr. Lussos posited that persons in chronic pain can use other quantifiable measurements to describe their pain. Given the overwhelming persuasiveness of quantification in medical and scientific contexts in the United States, Dr. Lussos posited that describing one's pain with numbers might be more persuasive than using a subjective description.

Dr. Lussos found that persons with chronic pain can describe their pain in quantified measurements but that these metrics were perceived as no more or less persuasive than other rhetorical moves. Participants often quantified their pain in terms of time: minutes they had to wait after taking medication before they could stand, hours they could sit before they were in agony, or years in which a part of their body could not function. Participants also described their pain by quantifying the expense of treatments, the amounts of medication or surgical interventions they used for treatment, or the limits in weight they could lift or distance they could walk. However, when participants described moments in which someone was convinced by their pain, overwhelmingly participants described moments when someone could "feel" their pain, because they themselves had pain or they could "see" the pain on the participant's face or body. So although these findings complicate prior scholarship that pain is reported in subjective terms only, the findings did not demonstrate that rhetorical quantification was more persuasive than other rhetorical moves that participants were already using, including simile, embodiment, and reticence.

Dr. Lussos determined that the best application of these findings was a message directed at people who do not have chronic pain but communicate with people who do. Therefore, Dr. Lussos drafted a one-pager that summarizes themes from the interviews, focusing on three areas: 1) why communicating about pain is difficult for the person in chronic pain; 2) the different options available for communicating about one's pain; and 3) actionable recommendations for those who want to help people who have chronic pain. Three national chronic pain advocacy groups have reviewed the one-pager, and two have agreed to share the information with their networks, including publication in one newsletter.

In addition to the one-pager, Dr. Lussos shared the results of her study in academic spaces. She presented her initial findings at the American Pain Society's 2019 Scientific Meeting, which included publication in the conference proceedings edition of The Journal of Pain. She presented her findings within her own field of writing and rhetoric, at the 2019 Association of Teachers of Technical Writing (ATTW) conference. She also presented her findings as a finalist in her university's 3MT competition, which aired on the gmu-tv network. Finally, she reported the initial findings in her dissertation, completed in May 2019.
